repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Erzincan Earthquake Rehabilitation
            and Reconstruction Project, Turkey Emergency Flood and
            Earthquake Recovery Project, and Emergency Earthquake
            Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings for the Erzincan
            Earthquake Rehabilitation and Reconstruction Project, Turkey
            Emergency Flood and Earthquake Recovery Project, and
            Emergency Earthquake Recovery Project are as follows: For
            all three projects, project outcomes are rated satisfactory;
            sustainability is likely; Bank performance is satisfactory;
            and Borrower performance is satisfactory. The institutional
            development impact for the Emergency Earthquake Recovery
            Project is substantial, while the other two projects
            received ratings of modest for this aspect. Lessons for
            disaster recovery suggested by the experience of these
            projects included: 1) The support the Bank promptly provided
            enabled people to survive, put funds into the economy, and
            was reported as highly preferable to in-kind support by
            beneficiaries. 2)  Greater accuracy of damage assessments is
            still needed to avoid unnecessary construction. 3)
            Addressing the social and economic recovery aspects of
            emergency projects, although difficult, is critical for the
            sustainability of the reconstruction investments. 4)
            Creating New Disaster Management Institutions takes more
            time than is available under one project. 5) Cash Transfer
            projects can make an extremely important contribution to
            recovery. Getting cash support to victims quickly positively
            affected the economy and perhaps even affected people's
            sense of safety and security. It was a prominent first sign
            of the government's support in a time of acute need.

            EARTHQUAKE RECOVERY PROJECT,TF040783-TURKEY: EMERGENCY FLOOD RECOVERY,TF039619-TURKEY - EMERGENCY EARTHQUAKE
            RECOVERY LOAN (BENEFIT ASSESSMENT SECTOR

abstracts.cdata!:
On August 17, 1999, a massive earthquake
            devastated Turkey's Marmara region. The World Bank
            provided 252 million dollars for emergency recovery
            assistance. Another 505 million dollars was provided for the
            construction of 11,502 new homes in eight different sites
            throughout the devastated region. Together, the World Bank
            and Turkish authorities also are taking steps to safeguard
            people against any future quakes. Two million earthquake
            insurance policies have been issued through the Turkish
            catastrophic insurance pool, and the Turkish emergency
            management agency has been established to respond
            effectively to future crises.

23906383.trustfund:
TF039619-TURKEY - EMERGENCY EARTHQUAKE
            RECOVERY LOAN (BENEFIT ASSESSMENT SECTOR

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Emergency Earthquake Recovery Loan
            (EERL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the is Emergency
            Earthquake Recovery Loan (EERL) Project rated as
            satisfactory, sustainability as likely, institutional
            development impact as substantial, bank performance as
            satisfactory, and borrower performance as satisfactory. The
            main lessons learned from this project include: 1) Better
            coordination is needed among and within Government agencies.
            2) Volunteers played a key role in mobilizing efforts to
            process applications for the various allowances. 3) The cash
            allowances were viewed as an important step in helping
            people cope with the effects of the earthquake, and to
            overcome the trauma and to reintegrate into normal life. 4)
            The management information system in the Social Solidarity
            Fund should be strengthened, so that it would be easier to
            check centrally against duplicate applications and other
            errors. 5) The amount of the World Bank EERL was not
            sufficient to cover all the payments made, and the SSF had
            to use its own resources to cover the cost of the rental and
            repair allowances. 6) Teamwork among the SSF staff, the
            volunteers, other Government agencies, and in some areas,
            non-governmental organizations was critical to successfully
            set up and implement the payment of the allowances. 7)
            One-stop shop was an especially effective way of processing
            the benefits. 8) On the Bank side, the fast disbursing
            nature of the loan was helpful in facilitating the timely
            delivery of allowances to earthquake victims.

5086126.trustfund:
TF039619-TURKEY - EMERGENCY EARTHQUAKE
            RECOVERY LOAN (BENEFIT ASSESSMENT SECTOR
5086126.majtheme: Economic management,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!: Turkey - Emergency Earthquake Recovery Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Through financing of imports and budget
            support the Emergency Earthquake Recovery Loan will assist
            Turkey to respond quickly and effectively to the impact of
            the devastating earthquake which hit the Marmara region on
            August 17, 1999. The benefits will be to provide financing
            for incremental private sector import needs resulting from
            the earthquake and for budgetary expenditures related to the
            recovery effort including social protection priorities. A
            key objective is to ensure that displaced persons and other
            groups made vulnerable by the earthquake receive adequate
            assistance particularly during the upcoming winter months,
            while longer-term reconstruction efforts get underway. The
            quick disbursing loan will provide: a) financing for a broad
            range of specified imports; b) financing of priority
            components for the earthquake recovery program (by the
            Government's use of the Lira counterpart of the foreign
            exchange proceeds); and c) limited funding for technical
            assistance. The loan is part of a larger assistance package
            from the Bank designed to complement project financing for
            reconstruction and disaster mitigation from the
            restructuring of existing projects and preparation of the
            Marmara Earthquake Emergency Reconstruction Project.

docna.cdata!: Turkey - Emergency Earthquake Recovery Loan Project
